instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Sometimes working - sometimes not
threads.message:
I got this MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

Came in dead. Does not have S0 Enables. So i measure diode mode on pin4 on <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> and it is low (around  0.065V). I injected voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>. But nothing gets hot and current draw is low (around 0.1A) 

Computer is working if i force S0 state by bridging pin4+5 on <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> but then of course doesn't sleep very well...

Any tips to find out what is causing the low voltage drop on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>?

Thanks

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Sometimes working - sometimes not
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Sometimes working - sometimes not
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Sometimes working - sometimes not
threads.message: That can only come from <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3210</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7870</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>. First remove <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR>/87 and see if that solves the low resistance. If not the <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> would be my first suspect and after that just start pulling the others.
